content.text: Definitions help us understand the difference between statements that are true by virtue of meaning and those that require observation to verify. This is one of philosophy's most important distinctions.

content.definition: A statement that is true (or false) solely by virtue of the meanings of its terms. No observation of the world is needed to determine its truth value.

content.title: Analytic Truths
premises: "Nothing can be red all over and green all over at the same time."
content.conclusion: These are true by definition - you don't need to go check.
content.note: Denying an analytic truth is self-contradictory.

content.definition: A statement whose truth value depends on facts about the world, not just the meanings of words. Experience or observation is needed to verify it.

content.title: Synthetic Truths
premises: "There are more than 50 stars in the Milky Way."
content.conclusion: These require looking at the world to verify.
content.note: Synthetic statements are informative about reality beyond mere meaning.

symbols.name: Known Before Experience
symbols.meaning: Can be known through reason alone

content.text: The analytic/synthetic distinction concerns the **source of truth** (meaning vs. fact), while a priori/a posteriori concerns the **source of knowledge** (reason vs. experience). These usually align, but some philosophers argue there are synthetic a priori truths (like 'every event has a cause').

content.question: Which statement is analytic (true by definition)?
options: The sun rises in the east
content.explanation: 'All sisters are female siblings' is analytic because it's true by the very meaning of 'sister' - a sister is defined as a female sibling. The other statements require observation to verify: gold's weight must be measured, dogs' loyalty must be observed, and the sun's rising direction must be experienced.
